artist: Artist: Attributed to Ventura Salimbeni; Artist: Formerly attributed to Francesco Vanni
description: sketchy figures; compositional lines (large X and horizontal line) drawn over image; collapsing woman in LRQ, supported by standing figure; woman has PR arm outstretched to standing saint, who holds out PR hand to her; other standing and kneeling figures
inscription:
Inscriptions and Stamps

bottom center, in brown ink: [N.ro 66 del detto Cav.re Ventura Salimbeni]; 
lower right, in pen and brown ink: [14.6.] (William Gibson\'s price code, cf. Lugt 2885);
upper left, in pen and brown ink, illegible [?7<>=?JB], unidentified collector\'s code;
on mount, bottom center, in brown ink: [Del Cav:re Ventura Salimbeni]

on paper laid down on verso, in pen and brown ink: 
[Vincenzio--------Benceni e Fran.co Guiducei p d\' Anc.a Conto mio - 42:7
Detti----------------Conto mio de ?<fare> ?77
detti----------------Conto loro ap.ro G.P 95]

Stencilled letters:  
in brown ink: [V]; in red ink: [C] /
in red ink: [V]; in brown ink: [D]
medium: Black chalk, pen and brown ink and brown wash; partially squared, with perspectival indications; laid down, in window mount
provenance: Unidentified collector, Lugt 2736, Italian (Florence), 17th century, associated with the Brandini family. Unidentified collector, Lugt 2898, probably English, 17th century, ('Jerome Lanier, d. 1657); Nicholas Lanier, Lugt 2885 (1588-1666), London. William Gibson, Lugt 5216 (1644'-d. 1703), London. Nathaniel Hone, Lugt 2793 (1718-1784), London. Sale, Christie's, London, July 4, 2000, no. 92, for £6,462, to Moir; Alfred Moir, Santa Barbara (2000-d.2010; bequeathed to Mia)
text: Many early collectors of drawings stamped the works in their possession with a personal collector’s stamp. This anonymous Italian drawing passed through at least five different collections in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries (see provenance below). Collectors often also annotated their drawings with inventory numbers, price codes, or the names of the artist they thought drew the work. Artists rarely signed drawings before the eighteenth century, certainly not informal sketches like the present sheet. Thus the attribution of this drawing to the Sienese painter Ventura Salimben (1568–1613), which is inscribed on both the mount and the drawing, was made by a later owner. That this drawing was in an Italian collection of primarily Florentine sixteenth and seventeenth-century drawings suggests that it may be Florentine instead. It was in England by the mid-17th century, perhaps as early as 1657, if the star stamp in the lower right corner can be identified with Jerome Lanier, who died that year [see Jeremy Woods 2003]. It was certainly in England before Nicholas Lanier's death in 1666.
title: Bishop Saint Exorcising Demons from a Woman
